step.action: CYCLIC FULL & FREE / CENTERED - FRICTION ON
COLLECTIVE FULL UP AND DOWN - FRICTION ON
ALL OFF EXCEPT ANTI-COL ON & MASTER GYRO SWITCH ON
IN EXCEPT FUEL BOOST CBs OUT
CHECK LOW RPM AUDIO AND LIGHT
[IN] CHECK PRESSURE - FUEL PUMP CAUTION LIGHT ON
[IN] CHECK PRESSURE - FUEL PUMP CAUTION LIGHT OFF
[OUT] CHECK PRESSURE - FUEL PUMP CAUTION LIGHT ON
[IN] CHECK PRESSURE - FUEL PUMP CAUTION LIGHT OFF
MIN 24 VOLTS, MIN 19 VOLTS DURING START
MONITOR 810-840 bhs (810-927 BELL) FOR 10 SECS DURING START MAX PEAK 927 ON START
ENG OUT & TRANS OIL PRESS LIGHTS OUT
UNLESS ENGINE SHUTDOWN LESS THAN 15 MINUTES AGO
BATTERY MASTER ON - DISCONNECT EXTERNAL POWER
ON - CHECK LOAD METER AND VOLT METER

stage.stagetitle: NOTE: NOT REQUIRED IF FLIGHT IS BY SAME CREW IN SAME AIRCRAFT ON THE SAME DAY

step.action: ON - NOTE TOT RISE - OFF - TOT DECREASE
ON - NOTE LOAD METER INCREASE - OFF
OPEN - NO CHANGE IN TOT - CLOSE

THROTTLEFULL | CHOP THROTTLE TO IDLE - NOTE N1 63%-65% IN MORE THAN 3 SECONDS

step.action2: SAS LIGHT - ON (GREEN)
step.action3: MOVE CYCLIC - RELEASE CYCLIC RETURNS TO ORIGINAL POSITION

step.action2: T'S & P'S'
step.action4: INSTRUMENTS SET AS REQD, NO FLAGS

LANDING AND NIGHT SCANNER AS REQUIRED
TORQUE REQUIRED TO HOVER IS % GIVING CAT 1,2,3 OR 4 POWER

step.action2: BALANCE BALL FREE
BALANCE BALL FREE
RAD ALT, ISVI's, ALTIMETERs INCREASING

step.item: H E F F R R
CONTROL LOCKS FOR CYCLIC AND COLLECTIVE

step.notes: ZERO PSI IF BOTH PUMPS FAIL BELOW 6000FT IS PERMISSABLE

step.item: MINIMUM PILOT WEIGHT Fuel 75USG or less

step.action: When walking to the helicopter note its general condition and how it is sitting on the ground. Look for fluids on the fuselage or the ground. Look for anything unusual that catches your eye

On or Off as required. Door pins, gas struts and retaining straps are installed. If fitted with jetisonable front doors, ensure the release pins on both the crew doors project at least 1/2 inch (13mm) through the door lugs with the jettison handle in the correct position
Windows are cleaned, window sliders are intact
Fitted correctly and the locking pins and canon plugs are in place
Ensure the covers, earthing lead front tie down, pitot cover, engine intake and exhaust covers are all removed

stage.stagetitle: PRE FLIGHT INS - COCKPIT INS AND FUEL DRAIN

step.action: Check the general condition of the cockpit, instruments, radios, harnesses and controls
Ensure Maintenance Release, Flight Manual and Daily Flight Record are available and certified
Check fire extinguisher, first aid kit, survival equipment is on board
Depress button and check fuel for water or contaminants
ON (circuit breakers IN and check fuel pressure)
Take sample and check for water or contaminants
Press test button and check for A/F Filter caution light
Check that all internal lights are working
Check all external lights are working
Ensure all loose articles such as helmet bags, cargo etc. are secured
Progressively check the fuselage condition and in particular look for ripples,cracks, voids and chaffing
Caution and security. Check landing gear for cracks, tube deflection, loose rivets, rubber bushes and saddle clampscorrectly located.

step.action2: 1. First aid kit - Condition and security
step.action4: 3. Harnesses - Condition and security. Check attachment points

step.action: Visually check contents and ensure cap chain are secure

step.item: CABIN ROOF, TRANSMISSION FARING, ENGINE INLET AREA
step.action: Condition and security, cleaned of all debris
Check level (full to 1/2 full). Check cap and pin security
Condition, security and leaks. Pivot bolts can be rotated.

stage.stagetitle: EXTERIOR INS - TRANSMISSION AREA RIGHT SIDE

step.action: Check. (Oil level 1/2 to just visible). If on a slope it may give a false indication
step.caution: WHEN OIL LEVEL IN THE TRANSMISSION IS VERY LOW, IT MAY INDICATE AN OIL LEAK FROM THE TRANSMISSION SYSTEM TO THE ENGINE OIL SYSTEM. TO ESTABLISH IT IS NOT OIL DRAINING TO THE FREEWHEEL UNIT, TURN MAIN ROTOR BLADES BACKWARDS. IF LEVEL IS STILL LOW, CHECK THE ENGINE OIL RESERVOIR BY REMOVING THE OIL FILLER CAP. IF IT OVERFLOWS, MAINTENANCE ACTION IS REQUIRED BEFORE FLIGHT

step.action2: 1. Pylon support link (MOUNT) — No cracks, self-locking nuts secure
step.action4: 3. Isolation mount cover and bearing — Condition and security
step.action6: 5. Main drive shaft (old style). Check condition and TEMP-PLATES - Check for signs of grease discharge which will ground the aircraft
step.action7: 6. Main drive shaft (new style). The KAYFLEX coupling has no TEMP-PLATES or grease points. Check for general condition and all nuts and bolts are secure

stage.stagetitle: EXTERIOR INS - AIR INTAKE AREA RIGHT SIDE

step.action: Secured, all plugs and covers removed
Condition, cleanliness and clear of obstructions

stage.stagetitle: EXTERIOR INS - ENGINE BAY RIGHT SIDE

step.action: Main drive shaft (old style). Check condition and TEMP-PLATES
step.action2: Check for signs of grease discharge which will ground the aircraft
step.action3: Main drive shaft (new style). The KAYFLEX coupling has no TEMP-PLATES or grease points. Check for general condition and all nuts and bolts are secure

step.action: 1. Engine condition, security of attachments, no oil or air leaks
step.action2: 2. Engine mounts, secure and condition
step.action4: 4. Compressor wash tap is CLOSED and wire clip in place
step.action6: 6. Air discharge tubes - Condition and security. Check for any gas leaks around the joins
step.action10: 10. Gas producer fuel control - Condition and security
step.action11: 11. Fuel and oil lines – No leaks
step.action12: 12. Starter generator - Condition and wiring and cooling scoop clear of obstructions
step.action15: 15. Throttle linkages - split pins in place

step.action: Check quantity. No lower than 1.5 on the dip stick and should be checked within 20 minutes of shutdown. You may get false readings if checking prior to the first flight of the day
step.action2: If it overflows cross check with the transmission oil level and consult an instructor or engineer

step.action: This can be very difficult to replace. Ensure the lever is rotated full OPEN then line up the markings before trying to close the cap. Pilots must use a ladder and take time to ensure the oil cap is replaced properly before flight
Condition and security. Check no metal contact between the tail boom and fuselage skin. There should be a small gap
Condition, no bare metal, scratches or dents

step.action2: 1. Drain holes — Clear

Remove and rotate the blades to the 10 and 4 o’clock position ready for starting

step.action: Condition. Look for rippling or distortion of the skin

step.action6: 5. Facet oil filter – Check the Red Button has not extended

step.action4: Tail rotor blades – no cracks, dents, chips or delamination

step.item: CABIN ROOF, TRANSMISSION FARING, ENGINE INLET AREA
step.action: Condition and security, cleaned of all debris
Cover removed and stowed in the pilots door pocket
Wait in the helicopter until the main rotor blades have completely stopped turning
step.warning: ATTEMPTING TO CATCH THE MAIN ROTOR BLADE WHILE IT IS STILL TURNING CAN CAUSE INJURY TO PERSONNEL AND DAMAGE TO THE AIRCRAFT

step.action: Note the remaining fuel quantity and calculate the next fuel load to inform the refueller

step.action1: 2. Tie down the main rotor blades
step.action2: 3. Cover the instrument console
step.action4: 5. Cover the aircraft if it is the last flight of the day
step.action5: 6. Conduct a walk around inspection looking for damage to the fuselage and rotor blades. Inspect for any oil leaks
step.notes: IT IS PREFERABLE TO TURN THE MAIN ROTOR BLADES BACKWARDS WHEN TYING THEM DOWN. THIS IS TO HELP ELEVIATE TURBINE RUB OR CARBON BUILD UP ON THE LABYRINTH SEAL. IT IS NOT MANDATORY BUT A PREFFERED PROCEDURE. IF RESISTENCE IS FELT WHILE MANUALLY TURNING THE BLADES DO NOT FORCE IT BUT SEEK MAINTENANCE ASSISTENCE

step.action: Arrange for a refuel as required and note the amount of fuel loaded into the helicopter in the DFR
Check the oil level and replenish if required
Check the oil level and replenish if required
Check the oil level and replenish if required

step.action2: • SAR board

step.action: Sufficient for the sortie. Refer to the DFR and cross check with the fuel quantity gauge
1. Remove covers, plugs and any safety flags and stow
step.action2: 2. Remove instrument console cover
step.action5: 5. Un-tie the main rotor blades and rotate to the 10 and 4 o’clock position ready for start
step.action6: 6. Conduct a walk around inspection looking for damage to the fuselage and rotor blades. Inspect for any oil leaks
step.action7: 7. Ensure all cowls and inspection hatches are closed

step.action: Check that all internal lights are workingy
Check all external lights are working
Check quantity sufficient for the sortie
Depress button and take fuel sample
Open the fuel cap and visually inspect the level then close the fuel cap
Ensure all access panels are secured
Open the engine cowl and have a general check of the condition and security of the engine then close the engine cowl
Open the engine cowl and have a general check of the condition and security of the engine then close the engine cowl
Check for obstructions both left and right side
Closed and secured unless being used
CONFIRM indications (there is no need to turn the battery on)
Open the left hand engine cowl and insert the wedge that will force the bleed valve piston down
step.action2: The ‘REMOVE BEFORE FLIGHT’ tag shall be exposed

step.action: There are 2 taps, one on each side of the engine. Open both engine access panels to gain access to the taps
step.action2: Disengage spring clip and turn the tap 90 degrees to close
step.action3: The ‘REMOVE BEFORE FLIGHT’ tags shall be attached in a prominent place while the taps are closed

step.action: Turn on and purge the water hose line so you know there are no particles in the hose prior to connecting it to the compressor rinse attachment
step.action2: Turn off the water
step.action3: Open the left hand transmission access panel
step.action4: CONNECT the hose to the hose fitting. Check that it is LOCKED IN.

stage.stagetitle: COMPRESSOR RINSE - PILOT IN THE COCKPIT

step.action: PRESS to motor the starter motor
step.action2: Allow the N1 to reach 5% then give the command “WATER ON” to the pilot at the rinse cart
step.action3: Allow the N1 to reach 10-12% N1 or run for 5 seconds (+5 seconds) whichever comes first
step.action4: Repeat the above procedure another two times

step.action: When given the command “WATER ON” by the pilot at the controls, the pilot at the rinse cart will turn on the water to the hose
After the third time that the starter was engaged, release the starter and allow the engine to spool down
Confirm that water is draining from the engine into the engine pan
“WATER OFF” to the pilot controlling the rinse cart
Wait for 60 seconds to allow excess water to naturally drain from the engine
After 60 seconds engage the starter to purge any excess water from the engine
Turn taps 90 degrees to open and re-engage spring clip.
step.action2: ‘REMOVE BEFORE FLIGHT’ tags – removed and stowed
After start Engine Anti-Ice to be on for 2 minutes to dry out the air lines and purge any water remaining in the anti-ice system

step.action: A normal start shall be done within 20 minutes of the compressor rinse to dry the engine regardless of if the helicopter was programmed for a sortie or not

stage.stagetitle: ENGINE START & STOP PROCS - BEFORE START CHECKS

step.action2: Full and free movement

step.action: Full and free movement. Re-centred and friction ON
Full and free movement. Full down and friction ON

step.action2: ON | TEST | OFF | STOW (as required)
step.action3: Isolation Selection switch activate back to PIC (if installed)

step.action2: After start Engine Anti-Ice to be on for 2 minutes to dry out the air lines and purge any water remaining in the anti-ice system

step.action: In their static position and no damage
ALL OFF except ANTI COL ON
step.action2: (Day only - if Night some will be on)

step.action: All IN except FUEL BOOST circuit breakers OUT
ON (select BAT) - Unless using EXTERNAL POWER
ON (select BAT) - Unless using EXTERNAL POWER
The following warning lights should be showing:
step.action2: • TRANS OIL PRESS

step.action: Check Low RPM warning horn by raising the collective slightly then lowering it
step.action2: If fitted, some helicopters have an aural warning system giving the following messages:
step.action9: Press the acknowledge button to cancel

step.action: PRESS to TEST all the Caution and Warning lights on the main Caution / Warning Panel
Circuit breaker IN – Check pressure indication
step.action2: FUEL PUMP Caution Light remains ON

step.action: Circuit breaker IN – Check pressure indication
step.action2: FUEL PUMP Caution Light should be OFF

step.action: Circuit breaker OUT – Check pressure remains
step.action2: FUEL PUMP Caution Light comes ON
FUEL PUMP Caution Light should be OFF

step.action: Zeroed for start. The clock on the ADF may be used for the start

step.warning: DURING THE FIRST FEW SECONDS OF THE ENGINE START THE TOT WILL ACCELERATE AT A FAIRLY RAPID RATE AND SHALL BE CLOSELY MONITORED.
step.warning2: THE MANUFACTURER LIMITS FOR A HOT START ARE REACHING A MAXIMUM OF 927C OR EXCEEDING 10 SECONDS BETWEEN 810C AND 927C.AT BECKER HELICOPTERS WE HAVE A COMPANY LIMIT OF 840C MAXIMUM FOR A HOT START AND A MAXIMUM OF 10 SECONDS BETWEEN 810C AND 840C. IF DURING THE START THE TOT LOOKS LIKE EXCEEDING 840C OR THE 10 SECONDS BETWEEN 810C AND 840C THEN IMMEDIATELY CONDUCT THE ABORT START PROCEDURE BELOW. IF IN ANY DOUBT, ABORT THE START AND THEN IF NECESSARY TRY AGAIN.

step.warning: THE MANUFACTURER LIMITS FOR A HOT START ARE REACHING A MAXIMUM OF 927C OR EXCEEDING 10 SECONDS BETWEEN 810C AND 927C.AT BECKER HELICOPTERS WE HAVE A COMPANY LIMIT OF 840C MAXIMUM FOR A HOT START AND A MAXIMUM OF 10 SECONDS BETWEEN 810C AND 840C. IF DURING THE START THE TOT LOOKS LIKE EXCEEDING 840C OR THE 10 SECONDS BETWEEN 810C AND 840C THEN IMMEDIATELY CONDUCT THE ABORT START PROCEDURE BELOW. IF IN ANY DOUBT, ABORT THE START AND THEN IF NECESSARY TRY AGAIN.

step.action: Either the instructor or the trainee may announce: ABORT START
step.action2: The pilot in control of the throttle will immediately conduct the following:

step.action: Continue to PRESS and hold the starter button
step.action2: Press the INDENT RELEASE button

step.action: Continue to press until the TOT is below 300°C (right hand)
Circuit breakers OUT - left hand (this may be done by the NFP to assist the FP)
Circuit breaker OUT - left hand (this may be done by the NFP to assist the FP)
Monitor. When stable below 300°C release starter
Monitor N1 until it is below 10% which will mean the engine driven fuel pump is no longer able to deliver fuel to the engine
Another start may be commenced at the discretion of the PIC when:
step.action2: • The TOT is 150°C or less, and
step.action3: • The battery voltage is 24 volts or more, and
step.action4: • The pilot is sure there was no mechanical reason for the HOT START and it is likely to be successful on the second attempt, and
step.action5: • The full start checklist is commenced from the beginning, and
step.action6: • A minimum of 15% N1 is able to be achieved before the throttle is set to IDLE on the second start
step.action7: If in any doubt, contact the Chief Pilot / HOS or Engineering for additional advice
step.action8: If it was a genuine hot start (not a simulated practice) then enter the event into Air Maestro and the Maintenance Release

step.caution: A START SHOULD NOT BE ATTEMPTED AT N1 SPEEDS BELOW 12%. DELAYS IN EXCESS OF APPROXIMATELY 3 SECONDS BETWEEN ROLLING THE THROTTLE TO IDLE AND ACTUAL IGNITION MAY CAUSE A HIGH TOT ON START. IF NO IGNITION OCCURS WITHIN 20 SECONDS CARRY OUT THE ABORT START PROCEDURE. IF N1 DOES NOT ACHIEVE 15% CARRY OUT THE ABORT START PROCEDURE.

step.warning: IF IGNITION DID NOT OCCUR DUE TO THE IGNITOR CIRCUIT BREAKER NOT BEING SET IN THEN DO NOT ATTMEPT ANOTHER START UNLESS:
step.warning2: • A VENTING RUN HAS BEEN DONE WITH THE CIRCUIT BREAKER OUT TO PURGE ANY FUEL IN THE COMBUSTION CHAMBER PRIOR TO THEN CONDUCTING A NORMAL START OR
step.warning3: • THE SECOND START IS NOT ATTEMPTED FOR AT LEAST 20 MINUTES TO ALLOW THE FUEL IN THE COMBUSTION CHAMBER TO DRAIN AWAY BEFORE A NORMAL START OR
step.warning4: • THE CIRCUIT BREAKER REMAINS OUT, ANOTHER START IS EFFECTED AND ON REACHING 15% N1 THE IGNITOR CIRCUIT BREAKER IS THEN SET IN BEFORE ROLLING THE THROTTLE TO IDLE. THIS IS NOT A NORMAL START AND SHALL ONLY BE CONDUCTED BY EXPERIENCED INSTRUCTORS

step.notes: THE FOLLOWING IS A MANUFACTURERS GUIDE FOR THE DESIRED N1 STARTING SPEED VERSUS THE OUTSIDE AIR TEMPERATURE:
step.notes2: 15% N1 RPM WHENEVER THE OAT IS ABOVE 7C
step.notes3: 13% N1 RPM WHENEVER THE OAT IS BETWEEN -18 TO +7C
step.notes4: 12% N1 RPM WHENEVER THE OAT IS BELOW -18C

step.action: Untied and visible in approximately the 10 and 4 o’clock position

step.action2: If necessary run through again a full OFF | IDLE | FULL | IDLE | OFF

step.action: Check a<font color='#000099'> minimum of 24 volts before start</font> with no less than 19 after pressing of the starter button>
Monitor the N1. It should be rising
Note the rate at which the compressor spools up
step.action2: If it sounds slow and is slow, then this is an indication of a flat battery and the start should be aborted prior to light off – use Battery Cart

step.action: With TOT less than <font color='#cc0000'>150°C</font> and N1 passing <font color='#cc0000'>15%</font> set throttle to IDLE
Do not attempt a start with N1 speeds less than 12%
Monitor: The manufacturers limit is 810-927 for 10 seconds with a maximum of 927 for one second
step.action2: Typically there will be two (2) peaks during the start. Each helicopter and every start may vary so it is important for the pilot to monitor closely
step.action3: If TOT reaches <font color='#cc0000'>810</font> and is still rising prepare for an ABORT START procedure, ensuring your hands are in the correct position
step.action4: If the TOT needle continues to climb past 840, or it stays between 810 and 840 for 10 seconds then conduct the ABORT START Procedure (Company requirement)

step.action2: If not then conduct the ABORT START procedure
Transmission oil pressure light OUT

step.action: If the engine has been shut down for more than 15 minutes, hold the 63-65% N1 IDLE for 1 minute to stabilize the Starter Generator temperature
step.action2: If the first start of the day or during cold OAT operations, stabilize the engine at IDLE of 63-65% until the engine oil Temperature registers above 0°C
step.caution: AVOID IDLE RPM BETWEEN 50% AND 60% NR (ROTOR RPM) DUE TO RESONANCE IN THE TAIL ROTOR DRIVESHAFT. USE THROTTLE TO ACCELERATE THROUGH THIS RANGE WITHOUT DELAY

step.action2: • Battery Switch ON (BAT)
step.action3: • Disconnect external power and secure the cover

step.action2: Check load meter is reading above 0
step.action3: Check volt meter is 27 volts or more

step.action2: RAD ALT ON

step.item: CONTROL LOCKS FOR CYCLIC AND COLLECTIVE

step.action2: Check no hard over of the cyclic
step.warning: SECURE THE CYCLIC AND THE COLLECTIVE BEFORE TURNING THE HYDRAULIC SYSTEM OFF

step.caution: ENGINE ACCELERATION FROM IDLE TO FULL DURING GROUND OPERATIONS REQUIRES CLOSE MONITORING. A MAXIMUM THROTTLE APPLICATION RATE COMMENSURATE WITH A MAXIMUM OF 40% TORQUE IS EQUIVALENT TO APPROXIMATELY 10 SECONDS FROM IDLE TO FULL. THIS SHOULD PREVENT INADVERTANT AIRCRAFT MOVEMENT ON SLIPPERY SURFACES OR THE EXCEEDENCE OF ANY AIRCRAFT LIMIT

step.action: Check the N2 beep governor range. 97% to 102%
step.action2: Set 100% Nr

step.action: Select ON and monitor TOT for a rise then OFF checking for a decrease in TOT
Select ON and monitor load meter for a rise then OFF
OPEN the alternate air source for the engine air filter
step.action2: Monitor TOT: There should be no change (if there is a change, consult maintenance)

step.action: Move to check tip path plane and proper movement

step.caution: WITH THE HYDRAULIC BOOST SWITCH IN THE OFF POSITION AND WHEN MANIPULTING THE CONTROLS, BOTH HANDS SHOULD BE ON THE CONTROLS TO PREVENT INADVERTANT MOVEMENT THROUGH INTERMIXING OF THE CONTROLS
step.notes: UNCOMMANDED CONTROL MOVEMENT OR ‘MOTORING’ WITH THE HYDRAULIC SYSTEM OFF MAY INDICATE A HYDRAULIC SYSTEM MALFUNCTION

step.action: Check: Describe an X pattern with the cyclic moving approximately 1 to 2 inches or 30 to 60mm in either direction
Check: Raise approximately 1 to 2 inches or 30 to 60mm up then lower
OUT: Hydraulic system should be restored, then
step.action2: IN: Hydraulic system should be OFF

step.action: Chop to check low IDLE between 63 and 65% N1
step.action2: Limit from 100% Nr to 63-65% N1 greater than 3 seconds
Chop to check low IDLE between 63 and 65% N1
step.action3: Limit from 100%Nr to 63-65% N1 greater than 3 seconds

step.action2: 1. Master Gyro confirm ON and caged with no OFF FLAGS
step.action5: 4. Cyclic Force Trim button – PRESS and hold for 2 Seconds
step.action7: 6. Move the cyclic in an X pattern to confirm the ability of the pilot to override the force trim and when released the cyclic returns to the original central position. (Do not press the force trim button during this test)
step.action8: 7. Displace the cyclic and hold the position. Press the Cyclic Force Trim button for 1 second- NOTE the cyclic re-centres to new position
step.action9: 8. PRESS the Cyclic AFCS Release button once and you will receive an aural warning AUTO PILOT DISCONNECT (if fitted) or three short “beeps” followed by the SAS light ON (Steady WHITE) and the force trim will be OFF

step.action: QNH SET and checked that each is elevation ±100ft (VFR) or ±60ft (IFR)
HSI and magnetic compass aligned within 10 degrees

step.item: CONTROL LOCKS FOR CYCLIC AND COLLECTIVE

step.action: SET for 2 minutes for the cool down and stabilization

step.action2: RAD ALT OFF
step.action3: RADIOS OFF (Wait until blades have stopped in case there is a need to communicate outside the aircraft)

step.action2: If it does not decrease or starts to increase depress starter to motor and carry out the ABORT START procedure

step.action: Monitor to ensure it continues to decrease to below 10%
SAR noted, Fuel Time On Ground (FTOG) calculated, ATIS received
Caution and Warning lights are out
step.action2: Ts and Ps are normal
step.action4: Assigned altitude indicators (AAI) and RAD ALT SET
step.action5: AIs erect and no OFF flags
step.action6: Altimeters set and cross checked (±100ft for VFR. ±60ft for IFR)
step.action7: HSI and Compass aligned within 10 degrees

step.action: Amount of fuel stated. FTOG confirmed
Radios, navigation aids and transponder SET

Threat Error Management. Threats and errors discussed among the crew and mitigating strategies in place while still on the ground. This is to assist and speed up the TEM discussion between the crew when at the hover prior to departure and conducting the Pre Departure Brief
Landing lights and Night Scanner ON as required
Torque required to hover is _____% giving CAT 1, 2, 3 or 4
Optional for DAY VFR at the instructor’s discretion.
step.action2: Mandatory for IFR, NUA (NVFR) and NVG.
Ball free in the race
Ball free in the race
IVSIs showing a ROC

step.action: Pitch UP, DOWN, Roll LEFT and RIGHT indicated

step.action2: IVSIs showing a ROD

step.action: Airspeed alive CONTINUE once transitioning forward
step.action2: If it does not come alive then abort the take-off and return to engineering

step.action: We have CAT 1, 2, 3, or 4 Power available
The wind is coming from xxx at xx knots that gives us an into wind departure
My plan is to conduct a:
step.action2: • Standard airfield departure
step.action5: And climb straight ahead to XXX feet before conducting a left/right hand turn and setting heading for XXX on climb to XXX
step.action6: (Pilot will need to state what they are doing here)

step.action: Brief any wires in the area
step.action2: Brief any obstacles in the area
step.action3: Brief any identified threats relevant to the flight
step.action4: Nominate the last safe point of hover in the event of aborting the take-off

step.action: Brief any errors by the crew, air traffic, operations, internal, or external relevant to the flight
Questions: Ask the crew for their input and cover of any additional TEM points
Magnetic compass and HSI are aligned and heading is set to intercept track
step.action2: Heading bug is set to planned heading

step.action: Departure time is logged and the ETA for the next point is calculated

step.action2: Climb or Cruise power SET
step.action3: Pitot heat and engine anti ice as required

step.action2: Assigned altitude set
Next frequencies set
Wind, elevation, geography noted
Time on the ground confirmed
• No OFF flags
• Cross checked and within limits
step.action3: • Single Altimeter installation must be +60 feet of the aerodrome elevation for departure

• Dual Altimeter installations each shall be +60 feet of the aerodrome elevation for departure except one may be +75 feet on first leg only. This +75 difference is not permitted on the second leg and if present the flight may not go ahead.

step.action2: • Correct radio selected

step.action: • Power, Wind, Plan, Threat error management
step.action2: • Minimum visibility and ceiling

step.action: • In the event of an emergency VMC, remain VMC and return to land
step.action2: • In the event of an emergency IMC, continue to climb and conduct _________ approach
step.action3: • If there is an engine failure on take-off enter autorotation maintaining heading, or on departure enter autorotation and turn into wind. Conduct normal autorotative landing once visual

step.action: • Magnetic compass and HSI are aligned and heading is set to intercept track.
step.action2: • Heading bug is set to planned track.

step.action: • Departure time is logged and the ETA for the next point is calculated.
• Engine and instruments are within limits.
step.action2: • Climb or Cruise power SET as required.
step.action3: • Pitot heat and engine anti ice as required.

step.action2: • Assigned altitude set.
step.action4: • Auto pilot ALT activated on reaching cruise altitude.

step.action2: • Next frequencies set.
• Wind, elevation, geography noted.
• Time on the ground confirmed.

stage.stagetitle: INSTRUMENT CHECKLIST INBOUND - BEFORE 30NM INBOUND TO IAF

step.action2: • Calculate distance required to descend from the current altitude to the initial approach altitude at 500 fpm

step.action: • Load GPS approach procedure and check RAIM
step.action2: • Check the following captions on the GPS
step.action4: • TERM: Terminal less than 30NM greater than 5NM
step.action5: <font color='#41BA04'>LNAV</font> 2 miles from the FAF the CDI begins to transition to 0.3 mile full-scale deflection. If the system fails to transition to approach mode by the FAF a missed approach must be flown
step.action6: • Tune | Identify | Test the VOR and ADF if required

step.action2: • Frequencies briefed and set (Radio & NAV aids)
• Inbound direction of turn confirmed
• Inbound turn (time or distance) briefed
step.action5: • Minima confirmed (Altitude and visibility) MIN ALT and RAD ALT set
step.action8: • Final approach track and runway orientation and directions briefed
step.action10: • Missed approach procedure and next plan briefed
step.action11: • Crew actions at the MAPt / DA briefed

stage.stagetitle: INSTRUMENT CHECKLIST INBOUND - BY 25NM INBOUND TO IAF

step.action: • Obtain ATIS / AWIS and SET the QNH
step.action2: • Note the time

step.action: • Comm 1: Set to CTAF and Area or Tower and Ground as applicable
step.action2: • Comm 2: Set to Area (maintaining a listening watch) and PAL

step.action: • Contact ATC and notify TOD point and request diversion to intercept GPS approach or notify intention for aerial work and nominate a SAR time every 30 minutes. Note the nominated times
step.action2: • Request any IFR traffic for descent

step.action: • Activate the GPS approach procedure (to HOLD prior to the waypoint press OBS to deactivate or activate the next waypoint), or
step.action2: • Track to the NAV AID, or

step.action: • Landing light, navigation lights and strobes SET as required
step.action2: • Commence Descent

stage.stagetitle: INSTRUMENT CHECKLIST INBOUND - 15NM INBOUND TO IAF

step.action: • Make CTAF call: Position | Height | Intentions using VFR language

stage.stagetitle: INSTRUMENT APPROACH CHECKLIST - 10NM INBOUND TO IAF

step.action: • 10NM before the IAF conduct the pre-instrument approach checklist

step.action2: • QNH SET. Altimeters cross checked
step.action3: • Assigned Alt Indicator (AAI), MIN ALT and RAD ALT SET
step.action9: • GPS approach activated and RAIM checked
step.action10: • GPS TERM displayed if being used
step.action13: • Orientation to the runway noted and confirmed

step.action2: • MARKER BEACON – HIGH SENS / MONITOR ON

stage.stagetitle: INSTRUMENT APPROACH CHECKLIST - 5NM INBOUND TO IAF

step.action2: • Set the approach configuration (100kts ground speed Bell 206)

step.action: • GPS LNAV (or APP if older model Garmin430 displayed by 2NM if conducting GPS approach
step.action2: • VOR within half scale deflection
step.action4: • Make CTAF call “On Final” for runway XXX

step.action: • If visual, make circling approach and make CTAF call giving intentions or continue on a straight in approach
step.action2: • If not visual conduct the missed approach procedure and make CTAF / ATC call with intentions to make another approach, hold, divert or depart
step.action3: • GPS approach press OBS to conduct missed approach

step.action2: • Contact ATC to cancel SAR
step.action3: • Landing lights, strobes SET as required
step.action4: • Pitot heat and engine anti ice OFF

transstep.transitem: VFR in A,C & D IFR in E
Loss of radio (76 need a fix)

transstage.transstagetitle: WIND TABLE TO EXTEND OUTBOUND LEG FOR HOLDING

transstep.transitem: Make base turns at 60° in these conditions.

transstep.transceiling: Clear of cloud until attaining Vyse or Vmin IMC whichever is greater

transstep.transalternate: As per the DAP or LSALT + 500’ and 8km visibility

transstep.transitem: If A/C has a published PEC in the flight manual then apply that to the DA
transstep.transitem2: If the A/C does not have a published PEC then add 50ft to the DA (Bell 206 Jet Ranger)

transstep.transacc: Two (2) altimeters installed on IFR aircraft with current QNH set
If both altimeters show 60ft or less difference from the Aerodrome Elevation then OK for IFR flight
If one altimeter shows greater than 60ft difference but less than 75ft then OK for the first leg only for IFR flight.
If on the second leg both altimeters do not show 60ft or less difference from the Aerodrome Elevation then then IFR flight is not permitted
If either altimeter shows greater than 75ft difference from the Aerodrome Elevation the altimeter is unserviceable and IFR flight is not permitted

transstep.transpos: 2 lines at angles not less than 45° with any combination of aids.
If 2 NDBs both must be within 30NM of each other

transstage.transstagetitle: NAVIGATING BETWEEN RADIALS. POINT TO POINT

transstep.transptp: 1 - Base it on radials you are actually on and want to go to not headings
2 - Mark radial and distance from station to commence turn
3 - Mark radial to intercept and its distance from station
4 - Rotate bezel so that marks line up vertically from your position to where you want to go
5 - Read off heading to steer at top of index and count distance between the two positions
6 - Convert the distance to a time based on GS
